questions.text: A young girl presents with abdominal pain and a recent change in bowel habit, with passage of mucus in stool. There is no associated blood in stool and symptoms are increased with stress. The most likely diagnosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) The most likely diagnosis is Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) due to the following characteristics of the case: The patient is experiencing abdominal pain and a change in bowel habit, which is typical for IBS. The passage of mucus in the stool is also a common symptom of IBS. There is no blood in the stool, which rules out inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease. Symptoms are increased with stress, which is a hallmark of IBS, as stress can trigger or exacerbate IBS symptoms. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Ulcerative Colitis Ulcerative Colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that typically presents with bloody diarrhea (which is absent in this case) and abdominal pain. While stress can exacerbate symptoms, the presence of blood in the stool would be a more typical feature of ulcerative colitis. The absence of blood and the presence of mucus alone makes ulcerative colitis unlikely. C. Crohn’s Disease Crohn's disease is another form of inflammatory bowel disease, but it generally presents with more severe symptoms, including weight loss, fever, and abdominal pain. While it can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, it typically leads to bloody diarrhea, which is not reported in this case. The absence of blood in the stool and the mild symptoms make Crohn's disease less likely. D. Amebiasis Amebiasis is an intestinal infection caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica, which typically presents with bloody diarrhea or dysentery, often accompanied by fever and abdominal cramping. The absence of fever and blood in the stool, along with the chronic and stress-associated nature of the symptoms, makes Amebiasis unlikely.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for Irritable Bowel Syndrome of the constipating type:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lubiprostone Lubiprostone is the correct answer as it is specifically used for Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) with constipation. It works by increasing fluid secretion in the intestines, which helps soften stools and improves bowel movement frequency. Lubiprostone is commonly prescribed to relieve the constipation symptoms seen in IBS-C (IBS with constipation) and is considered effective in managing this type of IBS. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Cholestyramine Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that is mainly used to treat diarrhea associated with conditions such as bile acid malabsorption or chronic diarrhea. It is not used for constipation-predominant IBS. In fact, it may cause constipation as a side effect and is not indicated for IBS-C. C. Alosetron Alosetron is a medication used for IBS with diarrhea (IBS-D), not IBS-C. It is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that slows down bowel motility and helps reduce the frequency of diarrhea. It is not used to treat constipation but rather to alleviate diarrhea in IBS-D. D. Rifaximin Rifaximin is an antibiotic that is used primarily for IBS with diarrhea (IBS-D) and is thought to work by altering gut microbiota. It is not specifically indicated for IBS-C and would not be the first-line treatment for constipation-predominant IBS.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with weight loss and watery diarrhea. She also notices periumbilical pain and bloating after eating. She also complains of flushing episodes. On examination-rhonchi present, CVS-pansystolic murmur at tricuspid area increasing on inspiration noted. A small bowel x-ray reveals an area of narrowing and the lesion is surgically resected. The pathology report will be most likely
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carcinoid tumor. Carcinoid tumors are slow-growing neuroendocrine tumors that commonly originate in the small intestine, especially the ileum. These tumors can secrete various bioactive substances, such as serotonin, which cause the characteristic symptoms of carcinoid syndrome. The symptoms described—weight loss, watery diarrhea, periumbilical pain, bloating after eating, flushing episodes, and the presence of a tricuspid murmur—are classic features of carcinoid syndrome. Flushing and diarrhea result from the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances into the systemic circulation, particularly when the tumor metastasizes to the liver. The pansystolic murmur increasing on inspiration is consistent with tricuspid regurgitation, a hallmark of carcinoid heart disease caused by fibrotic deposits on the tricuspid valve. The narrowing seen on the small bowel X-ray likely represents a tumor causing obstruction. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice for localized carcinoid tumors, and histopathology confirming a carcinoid tumor would be expected in this case. Explanation for Incorrect Options: A. Polypoid adenoma Polypoid adenomas are benign growths typically found in the colon and rectum, not the small intestine. While they may cause localized symptoms such as obstruction or bleeding, they do not typically lead to systemic manifestations like flushing, diarrhea, or tricuspid valve involvement. The described clinical picture, including carcinoid syndrome, is not associated with polypoid adenomas, making this option incorrect. B. Leiomyoma Leiomyomas are benign tumors of smooth muscle that may occur in the gastrointestinal tract but are most commonly found in the uterus. While gastrointestinal leiomyomas can cause obstruction or bleeding, they do not produce systemic symptoms like flushing, diarrhea, or cardiac involvement. Furthermore, leiomyomas are not associated with serotonin or hormone production, which excludes this diagnosis in the given clinical context. C. Adenocarcinoma Adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor that commonly arises in the colon, rectum, or stomach. Small bowel adenocarcinomas are rare and typically present with obstruction, bleeding, or perforation rather than systemic symptoms like flushing and diarrhea. Adenocarcinomas are not neuroendocrine tumors and do not produce the hormones responsible for carcinoid syndrome, making this diagnosis inconsistent with the clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with dyspnea on exertion gradually progressive and fatigue. On examination pallor is present. Hb is 8.0 g% and Serum ferritin is low. There is no clinical history of upper or lower GI bleeding, but his stools are fecal occult blood positive. His colonoscopy is negative for any obvious sources of bleeding, but upper endoscopy reveals ulceration in the distal duodenum that is biopsied. What will be the most likely cause
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinoma is the most likely cause in this case because the patient has evidence of chronic blood loss and iron-deficiency anemia, as suggested by the low hemoglobin (8.0 g%) and low serum ferritin. Occult gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, which is indicated by the fecal occult blood positivity, often points to a source in the GI tract. The ulceration observed in the distal duodenum during the upper endoscopy is a concerning finding that strongly suggests a malignant process. Duodenal adenocarcinoma, although relatively rare, is a known cause of iron-deficiency anemia, chronic blood loss, and ulceration in the GI tract. Biopsy of the ulcer is essential for confirming the diagnosis. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Lymphoma While gastrointestinal lymphoma, especially in the small intestine, can cause similar symptoms (e.g., anemia, occult blood in stools, and fatigue), it typically presents as a mass or diffuse thickening rather than isolated ulceration. The biopsy findings in lymphoma would show a proliferation of atypical lymphoid cells, which is distinct from adenocarcinoma. In this case, the clinical presentation and endoscopic findings are more suggestive of adenocarcinoma than lymphoma. B. Leiomyoma Leiomyomas are benign tumors that arise from smooth muscle, typically in the esophagus or stomach rather than the distal duodenum. They rarely cause chronic blood loss or ulceration. While they can occasionally present with GI bleeding if ulcerated, they are not typically associated with the kind of findings seen here. Leiomyomas would not explain the patient's anemia and fecal occult blood positivity without additional mass-related complications. C. Lipoma Lipomas are benign tumors of fatty tissue and are usually asymptomatic. When present in the GI tract, they may be incidental findings and rarely cause symptoms unless they are large enough to obstruct the lumen or undergo ulceration, which is uncommon. They do not typically present with chronic blood loss or duodenal ulceration and are not consistent with the clinical picture in this case.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps for 3-4 months. He gives history of weight loss of 6 kg during this period. There is no history of fever, jaundice or abdomen distension. He is not on any medication. On examination- vitals are stable, per abdomen-no organomegaly. A small bowel x-ray shows diffuse nonspecific mucosal abnormality. Upper endoscopy is performed to visualize the small bowel and obtain biopsies. The pathology report revealed immunoproliferative small intestinal disease. The infectious cause for this abnormality is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Campylobacter. Campylobacter is a well-known infectious cause of immunoproliferative small intestinal disease (IPSID), also referred to as alpha heavy chain disease. IPSID is a rare form of lymphoma that is primarily associated with chronic infections in the small intestine. It is commonly observed in developing countries and regions with poor sanitation. Campylobacter jejuni, a gram-negative bacterium, has been implicated as a key infectious agent linked to this condition. Chronic Campylobacter infections lead to prolonged immune stimulation, contributing to the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells and the production of truncated alpha heavy chains, which characterize IPSID. The patient's symptoms of chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and mucosal abnormalities on imaging and pathology support this diagnosis. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Shigella Shigella typically causes acute bacterial dysentery characterized by high fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody diarrhea. It is not associated with chronic diarrhea or immunoproliferative diseases like IPSID. Furthermore, Shigella infections do not cause the diffuse mucosal abnormalities or the pathological findings described in this case. C. Salmonella Salmonella infections are typically linked to acute gastroenteritis, enteric fever (typhoid), or chronic asymptomatic carriage. While chronic Salmonella infections can occur in immunocompromised patients, they are not associated with immunoproliferative small intestinal disease or the production of alpha heavy chain proteins. Therefore, Salmonella is not the correct answer in this context. D. Yersinia Yersinia infections, particularly Yersinia enterocolitica, are known to cause acute enterocolitis or mesenteric lymphadenitis, mimicking appendicitis in some cases. While chronic Yersinia infections can lead to complications such as reactive arthritis, they are not linked to IPSID or diffuse mucosal abnormalities in the small bowel.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman complains of acute periumbilical pain that localizes to the right lower quadrant. She appears unwell, and on examination, there is tenderness and guarding in the right lower quadrant. A pregnancy test is negative and a pelvic examination rules out pelvic inflammatory disease. A clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis is made and she has an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy. The biopsy report showed acute inflammation and a tumor for which the appendix is a very common site of involvement. Identify the tumor
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carcinoid Tumor The correct diagnosis is a carcinoid tumor, which is the most common tumor of the appendix. Carcinoid tumors arise from neuroendocrine cells and are frequently found incidentally during appendectomy or other abdominal surgeries. In the context of acute appendicitis, the inflammation can coexist with or be triggered by the presence of a carcinoid tumor. These tumors are usually located at the tip of the appendix and are often asymptomatic, but they may occasionally present with appendicitis due to obstruction or inflammation. Histological examination of the resected appendix confirms the diagnosis, showing nests or clusters of uniform cells with granular cytoplasm and characteristic neuroendocrine features. Carcinoid tumors are generally slow-growing and have a low risk of metastasis, particularly if they are less than 2 cm in size. However, larger tumors or those with invasion into the mesoappendix may require additional treatment or follow-up to assess for metastatic spread. Why the Other Options are Incorrect: A. Leiomyoma Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors typically found in the uterus, gastrointestinal tract, or other locations with smooth muscle tissue. They are rare in the appendix and are not associated with appendicitis. Furthermore, the histological findings of leiomyomas—spindle-shaped cells with a whorled pattern—are distinct from the neuroendocrine features of carcinoid tumors. B. Lipoma Lipomas are benign tumors composed of mature adipose tissue. While they can occur in the gastrointestinal tract, they are exceedingly rare in the appendix. Lipomas are usually asymptomatic unless they grow large enough to cause obstruction, which could mimic appendicitis. However, the biopsy findings in this case were consistent with a neuroendocrine tumor, ruling out lipoma. C. Fibroma Fibromas are benign tumors of fibroblastic origin and are uncommon in the appendix. They typically present as well-circumscribed, firm masses, and are not linked to acute inflammation or appendicitis. The histological features of fibromas (spindle-shaped fibroblasts and collagen) are distinct from the findings in a carcinoid tumor.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with a 20-year history of celiac disease now presents with weight loss, cramps, and abdominal discomfort. She is adherent to her gluten-free diet, and is not taking any new medications. On examination, her abdomen is soft and there is fullness in the right lower quadrant. A small bowel x-ray reveals an area of narrowing in the distal ileum, and there is thickening and nodularity of the mucosal folds. She undergoes surgical resection of the lesion and specimen sent for biopsy. What will be likely cause of this presentation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Small Intestinal Lymphoma The most likely cause of this presentation is small intestinal lymphoma, specifically enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL), which is strongly associated with celiac disease. Patients with long-standing or poorly controlled celiac disease are at increased risk for this malignancy, even if they adhere to a strict gluten-free diet. Symptoms like unexplained weight loss, abdominal discomfort, and small bowel narrowing or thickening on imaging are red flags for a possible malignancy. EATL arises in the small intestine, often in the ileum or jejunum, and may present with obstruction, perforation, or a palpable abdominal mass. Biopsy findings usually confirm the diagnosis, showing malignant lymphoid cells infiltrating the bowel wall, often with associated inflammation or ulceration. This presentation—despite adherence to a gluten-free diet—suggests a complication of celiac disease, where chronic inflammation leads to lymphocyte proliferation and eventual malignant transformation. Why the Other Options are Incorrect: A. Refractory Sprue Refractory celiac disease is a condition where symptoms persist or recur despite strict adherence to a gluten-free diet. While it can also present with weight loss and abdominal discomfort, it typically does not cause localized small bowel narrowing or mucosal thickening on imaging. Refractory sprue is usually diagnosed based on the presence of intraepithelial lymphocytosis, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy on biopsy without evidence of malignancy. In contrast, this patient’s imaging findings and the requirement for surgical resection point to a more serious pathology like lymphoma. C. Tropical Sprue Tropical sprue is a malabsorption disorder seen in individuals living in or traveling to tropical regions. It presents with symptoms like diarrhea, weight loss, and nutrient deficiencies but is not associated with localized bowel narrowing or mucosal thickening. It is also not linked to celiac disease and is treated with antibiotics and folate supplementation. This patient’s history of long-standing celiac disease makes tropical sprue highly unlikely. D. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) IBD, particularly Crohn’s disease, could present with abdominal pain, weight loss, and small bowel narrowing. However, Crohn’s disease is not associated with celiac disease and does not explain this patient’s clinical context or 20-year history of gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Moreover, thickening and nodularity of mucosal folds on imaging are more suggestive of lymphoma in this case than the inflammatory changes seen in IBD.
